articles.headline: At Wal-Mart, Labeling to Reflect Green Intent
articles.snippet: The company is expected on Thursday to announce the creation of an indexing system meant to help retailers determine the social and environmental impact of their products.
articles.abstract: The company is expected on Thursday to announce the creation of an indexing system meant to help retailers determine the social and environmental impact of their products.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shoppers expect the tags on Wal-Mart items to have rock-bottom prices. In the future they may also have information about the product’s carbon footprint, the gallons of water used to create it, and the air pollution left in its wake.

articles.headline: New Policy Permits Asylum for Battered Women
articles.snippet: The Obama administration reversed the Bush administration on an issue at the center of a legal battle.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration reversed the Bush administration on an issue at the center of a legal battle.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has opened the way for foreign women who are victims of severe domestic beatings and sexual abuse to receive asylum in the United States. The action reverses a Bush administration stance in a protracted and passionate legal battle over the possibilities for battered women to become refugees.

articles.headline: At a Factory, the Spark for China’s Violence
articles.snippet: How a four-hour clash in a walkway between factory dormitories unleashed national bloodshed.
articles.abstract: How a four-hour clash in a walkway between factory dormitories unleashed national bloodshed.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHAOGUAN, China  The first batch of Uighurs, 40 young men and women from the far western region of Xinjiang, arrived at the Early Light Toy Factory here in May, bringing their buoyant music and speaking a language that was incomprehensible to their fellow Han Chinese workers.

articles.headline: CIT Says It Won’t Get More U.S. Aid
articles.snippet: The troubled lender CIT Group said that its talks with the government had ended and it was exploring alternatives.
articles.abstract: The troubled lender CIT Group said that its talks with the government had ended and it was exploring alternatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: The survival of one of the nation’s largest commercial lenders, the CIT Group, was thrown into doubt late Wednesday after federal officials rebuffed pleas to rescue the struggling company a second time.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Eric Dash

articles.headline: To Sleep, Perchance to Analyze
articles.snippet: An all-purpose alarm clock won’t tuck you in, but it will analyze your sleep patterns and suggest ways to improve your snoozing.
articles.abstract: An all-purpose alarm clock won’t tuck you in, but it will analyze your sleep patterns and suggest ways to improve your snoozing.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last nine years, I’ve reviewed nearly 1,000 products for The New York Times. Can you guess what every single one of them has had in common?

articles.headline: Future Nominations Are at Stake in Hearings
articles.snippet: Some of the rhetorical fire over the confirmation of Judge Sonia Sotomayor is aimed at President Obama’s next Supreme Court pick.
articles.abstract: Some of the rhetorical fire over the confirmation of Judge Sonia Sotomayor is aimed at President Obama’s next Supreme Court pick.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As the two parties skirmish over the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Sonia Sotomayor, some of their rhetorical fire is aimed not at her but at the next justice President Obama may get to pick.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Twitter Hack Raises Flags on Security
articles.snippet: A hacker showed the importance of security by exposing confidential information about Twitter after breaking into an employee’s e-mail account.
articles.abstract: A hacker showed the importance of security by exposing confidential information about Twitter after breaking into an employee’s e-mail account.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  You might think your password protects the confidential information stored on Web sites. But as Twitter executives discovered, that is a dangerous assumption.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Brad Stone

articles.headline: For Clinton, ’09 Campaign Is for Her Turf
articles.snippet: In a major speech, the secretary of state seemed to battle a perception that the State Department has lost influence to an assertive White House.
articles.abstract: In a major speech, the secretary of state seemed to battle a perception that the State Department has lost influence to an assertive White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton stepped back to center stage here on Wednesday to present an ambitious blueprint for America’s role in the world, the State Department billed it as a major foreign policy address.

articles.headline: Card Fees Pit Retailers Against Banks
articles.snippet: As the use of credit and debit cards has grown over the last decade, merchants argue that the attendant fees have sharply lifted the cost of doing business.
articles.abstract: As the use of credit and debit cards has grown over the last decade, merchants argue that the attendant fees have sharply lifted the cost of doing business.
articles.lead_paragraph: The most profitable item at Patricia Orzano’s 7-Eleven store on Long Island is coffee. Slurpees are a distant second.

articles.headline: Retailer Knockoffs Abound in India
articles.snippet: As Western brands try to enter the country’s market, foreign companies and governments alike are protesting the country’s lack of intellectual property protections.
articles.abstract: As Western brands try to enter the country’s market, foreign companies and governments alike are protesting the country’s lack of intellectual property protections.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI  Retailers are flocking to India, thanks to an economy that is still growing and a young population eager to gobble up new brand names.

articles.headline: Two Giants Emerge From Wall Street Ruins
articles.snippet: A new order is emerging on Wall Street — one in which Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase are starting to tower over former financial titans.
articles.abstract: A new order is emerging on Wall Street — one in which Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase are starting to tower over former financial titans.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new order is emerging on Wall Street after the worst crisis since the Great Depression  one in which just a couple of victors are starting to tower over the handful of financial titans that used to dominate the industry.

articles.headline: With Credit Markets Still Frozen, CIT Shops for Investors
articles.snippet: CIT was deep in negotiations with investors late Thursday, hoping to persuade them to provide the company with $2 billion to $3 billion.
articles.abstract: CIT was deep in negotiations with investors late Thursday, hoping to persuade them to provide the company with $2 billion to $3 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: The grim news from Washington arrived Wednesday afternoon at the Fifth Avenue offices of Jeffrey M. Peek: His teetering empire, the 101-year-old CIT Group, would get no bailout this time.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Michael J. de la Merced
